verses.text: My brothers, do not hold your faith in our glorious Lord Jesus Christ with an attitude of favoritism.
verses.comment: James warns believers not to mix faith in Christ with partiality. The term 'glorious' reflects Christ's divine majesty (cf. John 1:14).

verses.text: For if a man wearing a gold ring and fine clothes comes into your assembly, and a poor man in dirty clothes also comes in,
verses.comment: Illustrates the setting of favoritism with a public gathering of believers. Assembly hints at early Christian liturgical meetings.

verses.text: and you pay special attention to the one wearing the fine clothes, and say, ‘Sit here in a good seat,’ and to the poor man, ‘Stand there, or sit at my feet,’
verses.comment: James condemns discriminating behavior. Christ taught humility and honoring the lowly (Luke 14:10).

verses.text: have you not made distinctions among yourselves and become judges with evil thoughts?
verses.comment: Partiality makes one a judge with motives that are contrary to God’s justice (Matt. 7:1–2).

verses.text: Listen, my beloved brothers: has God not chosen the poor of this world to be rich in faith and heirs of the kingdom which He has promised to those who love Him?
verses.comment: James echoes Christ’s teaching that the poor in spirit inherit the kingdom (Matt. 5:3), highlighting God’s gracious choice and the promise to those who love Him.

verses.text: But you have dishonored the poor man. Is it not the rich who oppress you and drag you into court?
verses.comment: Unjust preference for the rich leads to oppression, which contradicts God’s justice for the poor (Ps. 82:3).

verses.text: Do they not blaspheme the honorable name by which you have been called?
verses.comment: The 'name' refers to belonging to Christ; being Christian means bearing His name, a matter of honor and witness (Acts 11:26).

verses.text: If you truly fulfill the royal law according to the Scripture, ‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself,’ you do well.
verses.comment: The 'royal law' is the supreme commandment of love (Lev. 19:18; Matt. 22:39). James points to the unity and perfection of the law of Christ.

verses.text: But if you show partiality, you are committing sin and are convicted by the law as lawbreakers.
verses.comment: Favoritism is not a minor failing but a serious sin against the law of God (Rom. 2:11).

verses.text: For whoever keeps the whole law but fails in one point has become guilty of all.
verses.comment: A reminder that the law is a unified whole; breaking one part brings guilt for all (Gal. 3:10).

verses.text: For He who said, ‘Do not commit adultery,’ also said, ‘Do not murder.’ If you do not commit adultery but do murder, you have become a lawbreaker.
verses.comment: James teaches that all God's commands come from one Lawgiver; selective obedience is rebellion.

verses.text: So speak and so act as those who are to be judged under the law of liberty.
verses.comment: The 'law of liberty' refers to Christ's law that frees the believer for true obedience (John 8:36). Judgment and mercy go together in the new covenant.

verses.text: For judgment is without mercy to the one who has shown no mercy. Mercy triumphs over judgment.
verses.comment: God’s mercy poured out calls believers to practice mercy. The theme echoes Christ's Beatitudes (Matt. 5:7).

verses.text: What good is it, my brothers, if someone says he has faith but does not have works? Can that faith save him?
verses.comment: James challenges the idea of a fruitless faith. True faith necessarily produces good works (Matt. 7:21; Rom. 2:13).

verses.text: If a brother or sister is without clothing and in need of daily food,
verses.comment: James draws a concrete example from daily life, which echoes Jesus’ own standard for the final judgment (Matt. 25:35-36).

verses.text: and one of you says to them, ‘Go in peace; be warmed and filled,’ but you do not give them what is necessary for the body, what good is that?
verses.comment: Good intentions are worthless without real acts of charity (see also 1 John 3:17).

verses.text: In the same way, faith by itself, if it does not have works, is dead.
verses.comment: Faith is completed and made alive by works (Gal. 5:6). The spiritual life of faith presupposes visible action.

verses.text: But someone will say, ‘You have faith and I have works.’ Show me your faith without works, and I will show you my faith by my works.
verses.comment: True faith is necessarily demonstrated outwardly (see also Matt. 7:16-20).

verses.text: You believe that God is one. You do well. Even the demons believe—and shudder!
verses.comment: Assent to God’s oneness is not enough; even fallen spirits acknowledge it (see Deut. 6:4). Real faith involves heart and will, not just intellectual agreement.

verses.text: Do you want to be shown, you foolish person, that faith apart from works is useless?
verses.comment: Empty faith is unproductive. The contrast highlights the necessity of obedience and works joined to faith.

verses.text: Was not our father Abraham justified by works when he offered up his son Isaac on the altar?
verses.comment: James points to a living faith, completed by Abraham’s obedience (see Gen. 22). The concept of justification here points to the demonstration, not initial declaration, of righteousness.

verses.text: You see that faith was active together with his works, and by works faith was made complete.
verses.comment: Faith and works cooperate together, leading to perfection (Heb. 11:17–19). Highlights the harmony of faith and action.

verses.text: And the Scripture was fulfilled that says, ‘Abraham believed God, and it was counted to him as righteousness’—and he was called a friend of God.
verses.comment: James sees Abraham’s completed obedience as the fulfillment of his faith. True belief is lived, not only professed (see Gen. 15:6).

verses.text: You see that a person is justified by works, and not by faith alone.
verses.comment: James asserts that true justification is more than verbal assent; works are necessary evidence. This harmonizes with the teaching that participation in the life of grace and obedience is essential for salvation (cf. Matt. 12:37).

verses.text: In the same way, was not Rahab the prostitute also justified by works when she received the messengers and sent them out by another way?
verses.comment: Rahab’s faith is shown by her actions on behalf of God’s people (Josh. 2; Heb. 11:31). Her cooperation with God demonstrates saving faith.

verses.text: For just as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is also dead.
verses.comment: James concludes with a strong analogy: faith without works is lifeless. Genuine faith must be animated by works, just as the body must have a spirit (1 Cor. 13:2).
